column5: Am looking to find a spot to camp / fish where I can bring my boat (40hp). I would be tenting it but would like to bring my 15ft aluminum for fishing as well. So far the front runner is Massassauga Provincial Park. Any suggestions?Pretty wide open on species. I prefer Walleye or bass personally.Thanks
Also, I am coming up from Hamilton so would prefer <5 hour drive.
I think you've made the right choice...
www.ontarioparks.com/park/ivanhoelake   Phone: 705-899-2644 Address: 170 Ivanhoe Lake Road PO Box 191 Foleyet, ON, P0M 1T0  fully equipped park for campers in the great north.
Ivanhoe seems a bit far (10hrs).... I'll keep it in mind for a different trip though.
Algonquin allows boats on Lake Opeogno.  Motor boats are allowed on some other lakes too; but some of them may have horsepower limits.
http://www.ontarioparks.com/park/sturgeonbay  Lots of sheltered water for a smaller boat?

as I mentioned on another site Restoule PP. Great park,great water sites,great fishing for walleye,bass,musky,pike and lake trout,hiking trails,very little pressure,back lakes and North Bay only 40 minutes away.If you need any other info on the park ,fishing and suggestions for which sites are best just ask.

You can make Temagami in 5 hours... camp for free on one of the many crown land campsites and if needed slip over to the PPark and use the comfort station for free, just like half the cottagers do that don't have showers!  Launch for free, park for free, camp for free.. leaves enough money to cover the gas there and back, AND your Beer!

http://www.ontarioparks.com/park/bonecho  On Mazinaw lake in eastern Ontario,  What you'll like: •100 metre high Mazinaw Rock featuring over 260 Aboriginal pictographs •Great hiking trails from 1 km in length to 17 km in length •Interpretive Boat Tours on Mazinaw Lake and over to Mazinaw Rock •Camping experience for everyone: RV, car camping, backcountry, and roofed accommodations •Interior canoe-in and hike-in sites available •Friends of Bon Echo Art Exhibition and Sale .Lake trout, walleye, bass, whitefish and pike I believe
